results.title: Approach to science
results.brief_description: This film, made as a tribute to both Sir Ian Clunies Ross and the study of science, illustrates the intangible attitude of the scientist, and shows the place of observation, creative reasoning, assumptions and experimental verification. It also shows the hard grind and disappointments. Suitable for mid-upper Secondary School students. No other credits available.

results.title: Apprenticeship: I wasn't made to be a secretary
results.creator_credit: David Haythornthwaite, Elisabeth Knight and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Girls who have chosen to serve apprenticeships in such areas as stonemasonry, automotive mechanics and painting discuss why they decided on these traditionally male dominated stress. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Apples in Tasmania
results.creator_credit: Fred Whatham and Cine Austral Productions
results.brief_description: Traces the development and locations of the apple-growing industry in Tasmania. Illustrates activities related to the planting, culture, harvesting and marketing of apples. Narrated by Roger Climpson. Suitable for Upper Primary-Upper Secondary students.

results.title: Appearance
results.brief_description: Few of us are happy about the way we look. We are either too short or too fat; our noses are too big or the wrong shape. As more people resort to surgery to alter appearance, this program talks to people about what they’ve done and the effect that it has had on their lives.

results.title: Apemen of Africa
results.brief_description: The processes involved in pinpointing the appearance of humans on earth are discussed in this film. Fossils discovered in South Africa in 1924 bore evidence that humans first appeared in Africa, not Asia, contrary to prevailing scientific opinion. Shows how further discoveries by anthropologists proved without doubt the existence of a human-like creature who lived in Africa as long as three and a half million years ago. Narrated by E. G. Marshall

results.title: Anzac: a nation's heritage
results.brief_description: The ANZAC performance at Gallipoli is examined as are the towns that are there today and the graves that remain. Likens the ANZACS to the Greek heroes of ancient times. This is an edited version of a commemorative film made in 1965, 50 years after the landing of Australian and New Zealand troops at Gallipoli on April 25th, 1915. Highlights include memorial services in Australia, New Zealand and Britain, a re-enactment at Anzac Cove and scenes of Gallipoli and Troy today.

results.title: Anzac Day: World War 1 (Yrs 9-11)
results.brief_description: Presented by Richard Morecroft, this program looks at empire building alliances and events which led to the start of World War I. It presents the romance of war, life and death at Gallipoli and Australian campaigns in the Sinai desert and in Europe.

results.title: Anzac Day: World War 1
results.brief_description: Richard Morecroft presents an overview of Australian involvementt in World War I, concentrating primarily on the Gallipoli campaign. Provides background history ot the war, the reasons for Australia’s involvement, and details the events at Gallipoli whilst mentioning the arenas of combat in which Australian soldiers fought. Uses stills, archival footage, footage from propaganda and feature films related to World War I. Useful background to the story of Anzac Day, mentioning Simpson and his donkey, Turkish bravery and perceptions of the war. (SCHOOL PROGRAM ON THE GREAT WAR-SUITABLE FOR PRIMARY SCHOOL CHILDREN)
